message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of a thyroid gland should result in congenital hypothyroidism, but the normal physical examination findings suggest that the patient received adequate thyroid hormones during intrauterine life. This is most likely due to transplacental transmission of thyroxine from the mother. The other options do not provide a plausible explanation for the patient's normal physical examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of thyroid gland should cause hypothyroidism and abnormal physical examination findings. However, the normal physical examination suggests that the patient received transplacental transmission of thyroxine from the mother.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of both lobes of the thyroid gland suggests congenital thyroid dysgenesis. However, the normal physical examination is best explained by transplacental transmission of thyroxine during fetal development, which may compensate for the absence of the thyroid gland. The other options are not relevant to this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of thyroid gland suggests congenital hypothyroidism. Option A is the most likely explanation for the normal physical examination findings, as transplacental transmission of thyroxine from the mother can help maintain normal levels of thyroid hormone despite the absence of a thyroid gland. Lingual thyroid tissue, molecular mimicry of hCG subunit, and production of TSH-receptor antibodies would not explain the absence of a thyroid gland.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of both lobes of the thyroid gland suggests congenital hypothyroidism. The normal physical examination findings suggest that the patient was receiving thyroid hormone during fetal development. Transplacental transmission of thyroxine from the mother to the fetus can explain this. The other options do not fit with the presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of both lobes of the thyroid gland would typically result in congenital hypothyroidism, but the patient's normal physical examination suggests that he has been receiving adequate amounts of thyroid hormone. Transplacental transmission of thyroxine from the mother can explain this, as well as the mildly elevated TSH concentrations on neonatal screening tests. The other options listed are not relevant to this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of both lobes of the thyroid gland means that the patient has congenital hypothyroidism which usually presents with abnormal physical examination findings. However, in this case, the normal physical examination findings are best explained by transplacental transmission of thyroxine from the mother during gestation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of a thyroid gland would normally cause hypothyroidism, but in this case, the newborn has normal physical examination findings. Transplacental transmission of thyroxine from the mother likely provided the newborn with enough thyroid hormone to prevent hypothyroidism despite the absence of a thyroid gland.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In the absence of a thyroid gland, the newborn would normally be hypothyroid due to a lack of thyroxine. However, in this case, the normal physical examination findings suggest that the newborn received thyroxine from the mother in utero through transplacental transmission. The other options do not explain the normal physical examination findings in the absence of a thyroid gland.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of both lobes of the thyroid gland suggests congenital hypothyroidism. However, the normal physical examination findings indicate that the newborn received enough thyroid hormone during fetal development. This can be explained by transplacental transmission of thyroxine from the mother.
